The ongoing wars provided lucrative business for Western European traders and merchants.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Knights Templar was a holy order devoted to defending the fledgling crusader states founded during the First Crusade against Muslim reconquest. The king of Jerusalem allowed them to make their headquarters in the main temple of Jerusalem, from which they took their name. In exchange for this hospitality they swore allegiance to the throne of Jerusalem. They participated in several major battles and did very well; this increased their numbers substantially. Eventually their power grew so much -- to the point where they could field an army of almost 10,000 knights and still uphold their promises to garrison individual towns -- that the Pope decided to place them under his direct control.[PARAGRAPH:2]Templar valor in the Holy Land resulted in many rewards back in Europe; knights who fought under the red cross and white field of the Templars often found themselves with new estates and castles in their native countries. As a result the order became fantastically wealthy, as the Grandmasters shrewdly invested the order's wealth, using plunder to buy goods and sell them throughout the Mediterranean.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kings, however, often become jealous of wealthy organizations over which they have little or no control. The French king Philip IV, his treasury emptied and his debts monstrous from constant warfare, accused the Templars of heresy and blasphemy, and confiscated almost all of their wealth in France. Other monarchs followed suit, embarking on a program of persecution and repression whose goal was mostly to secure the Templars' money for themselves. Hundreds of Templars gave false confessions of heresy under torture, and others were burned at the stake. The order died out completely in the early 14th century when the entire Templar leadership had been murdered.
TEXT.German: [TAB]The Crusades were a series of military expeditions by European Christians between 1095 and 1270 A.D. intended to recapture the Christian Holy Land from Muslim control. The most successful was the Third Crusade, in which a tremendous force led by King Richard I and Philip Augustus managed to regain control over a number of cities along the Mediterranean coast and reconstitute the Latin Kingdom of Palestine. In addition to their more altruistic goals, the Crusades also served to extend the political and religious power of the Pope over a larger area of the world. This great burst of territorial expansion led to an increase in both the population and productivity of Europe. The ongoing wars provided lucrative business for Western European traders and merchants.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Knights Templar was a holy order devoted to defending the fledgling crusader states founded during the First Crusade against Muslim reconquest. The king of Jerusalem allowed them to make their headquarters in the main temple of Jerusalem, from which they took their name. In exchange for this hospitality they swore allegiance to the throne of Jerusalem. They participated in several major battles and did very well; this increased their numbers substantially. Eventually their power grew so much -- to the point where they could field an army of almost 10,000 knights and still uphold their promises to garrison individual towns -- that the Pope decided to place them under his direct control.[PARAGRAPH:2]Templar valor in the Holy Land resulted in many rewards back in Europe; knights who fought under the red cross and white field of the Templars often found themselves with new estates and castles in their native countries. As a result the order became fantastically wealthy, as the Grandmasters shrewdly invested the order's wealth, using plunder to buy goods and sell them throughout the Mediterranean.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kings, however, often become jealous of wealthy organizations over which they have little or no control. The French king Philip IV, his treasury emptied and his debts monstrous from constant warfare, accused the Templars of heresy and blasphemy, and confiscated almost all of their wealth in France. Other monarchs followed suit, embarking on a program of persecution and repression whose goal was mostly to secure the Templars' money for themselves. Hundreds of Templars gave false confessions of heresy under torture, and others were burned at the stake. The order died out completely in the early 14th century when the entire Templar leadership had been murdered.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Marco Polo was a trader, writer, and world traveler who lived in the late 13th and early 14th centuries. Starting as a young boy, he began traveling with his father and uncle, who were merchants and traders in Venice, along a route that would take him throughout Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. Throughout his life, he visited many places, bringing back detailed information concerning lands that no European before him had visited. Polo's book, "The Travels of Marco Polo", was the only source of reliable information on such exotic locales as Siam, Japan, Java, Tibet, and India that existed in Medieval Europe.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Despite the huge outlays of cash for research and study, cancer still looms as a terrifying and deadly plague on the human race. Although scientists and doctors have discovered many different forms of cancer, and have indentified some of the factors that can trigger the disease, a true cure still eludes modern science. A cure for cancer would put an end to the source of much suffering and anguish, and would allow millions of people who would otherwise be doomed to lead happy and productive lives.

TEXT.English: [TAB]After decades of struggle, women in the United States won the right to vote in 1920 with the passage of the 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. The achievement of women's suffrage was accelerated by the excellent record of women working in jobs traditionally held by men during World War I. Full voting rights were granted to women in Great Britain in 1928. Since that time, women have gained the right to vote in most countries in the developed world.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: [TAB]Charles Darwin, the main proponent of the theory of evolution based on natural selection, built up much of his evidence for this theory during a five-year voyage around the world. His voyage aboard the H.M.S. Beagle was instrumental not only in the establishment of his theory, but also in the application of the scientific method to the study of nature. Darwin published his theory of evolution in his book "On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection". His studies were so thorough that the scientific world never challenged his findings. However, his findings were, and continue to be, challenged on philosophical and religious grounds. Darwin's research opened many new lines of inquiry, and inspired a wave of new biological research.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ancient astronomers originally put forth the theory that the Sun was the center of our solar system, and that the planets revolve around it. This knowledge was lost during the Dark Ages, but was re-introduced in the early 16th Century by Nicholas Copernicus. Copernicus' research and theories form the foundation for modern astronomy. Copernicus collected his data from his observatory, a small room in the spire of an East Prussian cathedral. His research methods and observations also marked the rebirth of the scientific method, and were an important step in the advance of knowledge.

TEXT.English: [TAB]One of the earliest pieces of military literature is "The Art of War", written by Chinese general Sun Tzu in the 6th century BC. This book contained a detailed explanation and analysis of the Chinese military, from weapons and strategy to rank and discipline. Sun Tzu also stressed the importance of intelligence operatives and espionage to the war effort. Because Sun Tzu has long been considered to be one of history's finest military tacticians and analysts, his teachings and strategies formed the basis of advanced military training for centuries to come.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Leonardo da Vinci was one of the most celebrated painters of the Italian Renaissance. His most famous works include the "Mona Lisa" and "The Last Supper". Although best known for his art, da Vinci was also an accomplished observer and designer. Preserved in his sketchbooks are ideas for dozens of inventions, many of them centuries ahead of their time. These include designs for such devices as drawbridges, construction equipment, parachutes, and even helicopters. His scientific and technical drawings became the basis for the development of many of these modern devices.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The tomb of King Mausollos of Caria (from whose name the generic term "mausoleum" derives), a local Persian ruler, was not especially remarkable in its construction or size. Its status as one of the Ancient Wonders of the World comes from the dozens of painstakingly carved statues and sculptures that surrounded it. They depicted legendary and real people, and the noble animals of mythology and history. Inside the mausoleum was a great frieze, or wall-carving, depicting an epic battle between the Greeks and the Amazons, and topping the mausoleum's dome was a huge statue of a four-horse chariot. The Mausoleum and its statues survived until after the Crusades, when Christian knights founded a new crusader kingdom in Asia Minor, and used the already-carved stones of the Mausoleum to build castles. The statues, in turn, spread around the world, until British archaeologists began to collect and recover them. Some can be seen today in museums, but most have been lost or destroyed.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Sir Isaac Newton, a mathematician and physicist, is considered to be one of the greatest scientists of all time. He is credited with many important discoveries including the laws of gravity, the color spectrum of light, calculus, fluid dynamics, and an understanding of ocean tides. He also built the world's first reflecting telescope. For 32 years, he held the position of Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at Cambridge University, an important teaching post, where he continued his own research while instructing a generation of students.

For 32 years, he held the position of Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at Cambridge University, an important teaching post, where he continued his own research while instructing a generation of students.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Sir Isaac Newton, a mathematician and physicist, is considered to be one of the greatest scientists of all time. He is credited with many important discoveries including the laws of gravity, the color spectrum of light, calculus, fluid dynamics, and an understanding of ocean tides. He also built the world's first reflecting telescope. For 32 years, he held the position of Lucasian Professor of Mathematics at Cambridge University, an important teaching post, where he continued his own research while instructing a generation of students.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In 1519, Ferdinand Magellan sailed from Spain with the intention of reaching the spice-rich Malouccas Islands of Indonesia by sailing west, instead of east. Although natives in the Philippines killed Magellan, his expedition went on to prove conclusively that the world was round. More importantly, it proved that the Americas were indeed a New World. Magellan's expedition was one of the great sea voyages of history, and it inspired further expeditions by other explorers. The discoveries made along the way reduced the dangers to all the sea expeditions that followed.

TEXT.English: [TAB]As the lifespan of a human being has slowly increased over the centuries, a shift in medical focus began to take place. Infectious diseases, once the leading cause of death, began to be tamed by modern vaccinations. This allowed the field to spend more time combating those ailments associated with advanced aging, such as cancer and heart disease. This trend shows no signs of slowing, but rather accelerating. Modern technology permits sophisticated diagnosis and treatment of illness, while at the same time identifying their genetic roots.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Statue of Zeus at Olympia, the site of the original Olympic Games held to honor the king of the gods, depicted him as a massive ivory figure clad in robes and sandals of gold. The statue was almost four stories tall, with its head nearly touching the roof of the temple that housed it. The sculpture is described as exquisite in even the tiniest details by historians and writers of the day -- its robes intricately carved with designs of animals, flowers, and images of Zeus' children, and its base surrounded by sphinxes and other mythological creatures. Such a statue could not long escape the notice of greedy kings and warlords, and several attempts were made to steal the statue -- including one by the crazed Roman emperor Caligula. The statue was finally successfully stolen about the third century A.D., and was destroyed in a fire in Constantinople just after the fall of Rome. No images or accurate reconstructions of this, one of the lost Wonders of the Ancient World, survive today.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Few composers were more prolific or beloved than Johann Sebastian Bach. Bach, the most well known member of a gifted family of German musicians, was perhaps the finest composer of the baroque style of music. In his time, he wrote numerous choral and orchestral pieces. During his lifetime, he was renowned as an organist and music director of St. Thomas' Church in Leipzig, and many of his compositions were religious in nature. After his death, Bach's music gained worldwide appreciation.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Adam Smith is generally regarded as the father of modern economics. In his book "The Wealth of Nations", he analyzed the economic processes of supply and demand, and discussed how free trade and individual ambition would lead to both economic and social growth. Smith favored a political environment where the government would only become involved in business and trade to preserve justice and order. Smith's ideas of economics and the lack of government involvement form the basis of modern economic liberalism.

TEXT.English: [TAB]For centuries, mankind has been harnessing the power of rivers to move waterwheels for various purposes. With the advent of electrical power, it was found the rivers were also very useful for generating electricity. Hydroelectric power plants derive power from rivers by constructing dams to ensure a dependable supply of water. The overflow is then released through special chambers where the moving water turns giant turbines, generating electricity. When planned and engineered properly, this system provides an excellent power source with very limited environmental impact. The Hoover Dam, constructed on the Colorado River near Las Vegas, was one of the earliest hydroelectric power plants.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An "arcology" is a human settlement with an extremely high population density. To achieve such density requires near-total control over the settlement's environment. As modern cities have become ever more populated, they have repeatedly stressed their resources to the breaking-point. The largest human cities have become de-facto arcologies, and to survive have had to encase themselves in domes to increase their control over the populace and the environment. [PARAGRAPH:1]Domed cities are more efficient than undomed cities, exposed as the latter are to the vagaries of the environment and all manner of air- and water-borne disease. The climate in an arcology is kept at a constant temperature, ending the need for less-efficient individual heating and cooling units. The air and water supplies are constantly scrubbed to remove any disease or impurities, increasing the population's life-spans and decreasing pressure on the city's medical support systems. Meals are created and served at massive cafeterias, providing a more efficient distribution of protein and also removing the need for wasteful individual cooking units. [PARAGRAPH:1]Increased population density is not without its drawbacks, however. As populations increase the stress level is higher, as is the risk of mental illness or indeed total mental breakdown. The city's leaders combat these problems through education, increased psychological monitoring of the population, and, in extreme cases, by secretly slipping doses of tranquilizers into the citizens' food supply.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une "arcologie" est un bâtiment cré par l'homme pour accueillir une formidable densité de population. Pour rendre l'arcologie entièrement autonome, il est nécessaire d'en contrôler parfaitement l'environnement. A mesure que les villes modernes se sont agrandies, elles ont puisé dans les ressources environnantes jusqu'à un point de non-retour. Les plus grandes villes de la planète sont devenues, par la force des choses, des arcologies dont la survie a nécessité la création de dômes gigantesques qui permettaient un meilleur contrôle de la population et de l'environnement. [PARAGRAPH:1]Les villes "coiffées" d'un dôme sont plus efficaces que les autres. En effet, elles ne subissent plus les aléas de l'environnement ni la propagation de maladies par l'eau ou par l'air. Le climat dans une arcologie est maintenu à température constante, afin de rendre le chauffage et la climatisation inutiles. L'approvisionnement en air et en eau est constamment traité afin de supprimer tout microbe ou impureté, ce qui augmente l'espérance de vie des habitants et permet de réduire les besoins de la ville en infrastructures médicales. Les repas sont produits et distribués dans d'immenses cafétérias, ce qui permet un apport nutritionnel optimal et rend obsolète les nombreux échelons de l'industrie alimentaire classique. [PARAGRAPH:1]L'augmentation de la densité de population n'est pas sans présenter quelques inconvénients. A mesure que la population croît, le niveau de stress augmente et avec lui les risques de maladies mentales ou de dépressions. Les dirigeants de la ville combattent ces problèmes par l'éducation, par une surveillance psychologique accrue de la population et, dans les cas les plus extrêmes, par l'adjonction de tranquillisants à la nourriture distribuée aux citoyens.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine "Arkologie" ist ein von Menschen besiedelter Gebäudekomplex mit einer extrem hohen Bevölkerungsdichte. Um eine derartige Dichte überhaupt zu ermöglichen, ist eine nahezu lückenlose Kontrolle der Umweltbedingungen innerhalb der Siedlung erforderlich. Mit steigendem Bevölkerungszuwachs litten die modernen Städte immer wieder unter Ressourcenengpässen, daher wurden die größten Städte der Menschheit mit Kuppeln versehen, die das Überleben der Bürger sicherten und eine bessere Kontrolle der Umweltbedingungen erlaubten. Man bezeichnete dies als Arkologien.[PARAGRAPH:1]Durch Kuppeln geschützte Städte sind nachweislich effizienter als Städte ohne Kuppeln, die den Launen der Natur sowie allen Arten von Krankheitskeimen, die durch Luft und Wasser übertragen werden, ausgesetzt sind. Das Klima innerhalb einer Arkologie wird auf konstantem Niveau gehalten, so dass sich ineffiziente Heiz- und Kühleinheiten erübrigen. Außerdem werden die Luft- und Wasserversorgungsanlagen regelmäßig gereinigt, damit Schmutzpartikel und Krankheitserreger beseitigt werden. Dadurch steigt die Lebenserwartung der Bürger und die medizinischen Hilfseinrichtungen der Stadt werden entlastet. Die Mahlzeiten werden in riesigen Kantinen zubereitet und eingenommen, so dass eine wirksame Verteilung von Proteinen sichergestellt ist und die Notwendigkeit für verschwenderische individuelle Kocheinheiten entfällt.[PARAGRAPH:1]Eine hohe Bevölkerungsdichte bringt aber auch Nachteile mit sich, denn der Stresspegel steigt ebenso wie das Risiko für Geisteskrankheiten oder totale Nervenzusammenbrüche. Die Stadtväter versuchen diese Probleme daher durch Bildung, intensive psychologische Überwachung der Bürger und in Extremfällen auch durch die insgeheime Verabreichung von Beruhigungsmitteln im Rahmen der Nahungsversorgung zu bekämpfen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un'"arcologia" è un insediamento umano con una densità di popolazione estremamente alta. Per raggiungere tale densità è necessario un controllo quasi totale sull'ambiente. Le città moderne sono sempre più popolose e hanno ripetutamente spinto le proprie risorse fino al punto limite. Le più grandi città umane sono di fatto diventate arcologie, e per sopravvivere si sono dovute rinchiudere in cupole per aumentare il proprio controllo sulla popolazione e sull'ambiente. [PARAGRAPH:1]Le città dentro le cupole sono molto più efficienti di quelle all'esterno: queste ultime sono esposte ai capricci dell'ambiente e a ogni tipo di malattia trasmessa per via aerea o acquatica. Il clima di un'arcologia mantiene una temperatura costante, eliminando il bisogno di unità di riscaldamento e raffreddamento individuali. Le scorte di aria e di acqua sono costantemente filtrate per rimuovere malattie o impurità, aumentando la vita media della popolazione e diminuendo la pressione sul sistema sanitario cittadino. I pasti sono preparati e serviti in gigantesche mense, provvedendo a una più efficiente distribuzione delle proteine ed eliminando il bisogno di unità di cottura individuali. [PARAGRAPH:1]La maggiore densità della popolazione ha anch'essa dei lati negativi, però. L'aumento della popolazione porta a maggiori livelli di stress, così come a un maggiore rischio di malattie mentali o di totale collasso psicologico. I leader della città combattono questi problemi tramite l'educazione, un maggiore controllo psicologico della popolazione e, in casi estremi, immettendo segretamente dei tranquillanti nel cibo dei cittadin
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Una "arcología" es un asentamiento humano con una densidad de población extremadamente alta. Para lograr dicha densidad es necesario tener un control casi total del entorno del asentamiento. A medida que las ciudades modernas se han ido superpoblando, han llevado repetidamente sus recursos hasta el límite. Las mayores ciudades humanas se han convertido en arcologías de facto y han tenido que cubrirse con cúpulas para aumentar el control de la población y el medio ambiente. [PARAGRAPH:1]Las ciudades abovedadas funcionan mejor que las que no lo están, ya que éstas se ven expuestas a los caprichos del entorno y a todas las formas de enfermedades procedentes del aire y el agua. En la arcología, el clima se mantiene a una temperatura constante, lo cual acaba con la necesidad de sistemas individuales de refrigeración y calefacción, que son menos eficientes. El suministro de aire y agua se purifica constantemente para eliminar cualquier fuente de infección o impureza, lo que aumenta la longevidad de la población y reduce la presión en los sistemas sanitarios de la ciudad. Las comidas se hacen y sirven en enormes cantinas y aportan una distribución más eficiente de proteínas a la vez que eliminan el derroche que suponen las cocinas individuales. [PARAGRAPH:1]Sin embargo, el aumento de la densidad de población cuenta también con sus desventajas. A medida que la población crece también lo hace el nivel de estrés, así como el riesgo de enfermedades mentales e incluso el de colapso mental completo. Los líderes de las ciudades combaten dichos problemas mediante la educación, el aumento del control psicológico de la población y, en casos extremos, a través de la administración secreta de dosis de sedantes en el suministro de alimentos de los ciudadano

TEXT.English: [TAB]Bio-war labs are designed to create and mass-produce bio-weapons. In addition, they also work to create antidotes to the enemy's bio-weapons (as well as to their own). Thus these buildings are considered to be integral to a city's defenses. Despite this, and even though these Bio-war labs are equipped with sophisticated and layered defenses against containment breaches, such facilities are often quite unpopular with their neighbors.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les laboratoires de guerre biologique sont conçus pour créer et produire des armes biologiques. En outre, ils travaillent aussi à la mise au point d'antidotes, afin de lutter contre les effets des agents biologiques ennemis (ou alliés). Ces bâtiments font donc partie intégrante du dispositif de défense d'une ville. Toutefois, malgré la fiabilité de leur système de protection, ces installations restent très impopulaires auprès des populations riveraines.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Labors für biologische Kriegsführung dienen der Entwicklung und Massenproduktion von biologischen Waffen. Außerdem werden hier auch Gegenmittel für feindliche (und eigene) biologische Waffen hergestellt. Dementsprechend sind diese Gebäude integraler Bestandteil der städtischen Verteidigung. Obwohl die Labors durch hoch entwickelte Abschirmsysteme gleich mehrfach geschützt sind, zeigen sich benachbarte Nationen in aller Regel nicht allzu begeistert von ihrer Existenz.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]I laboratori per la guerra biologica sono progettati per creare e produrre in massa armi biologiche. Inoltre lavorano per creare antidoti per le armi biologiche del nemico (oltre che per le proprie). Per questo gli edifici vengono considerati parte integrante delle difese di una città. Nonostante ciò, e anche se sono equipaggiati con misure di sicurezza per impedire contaminazioni, questi impianti non sono mai molto ben visti nel vicinato.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los laboratorios de guerra biológica se han pensado para crear armas biológicas a gran escala. Además, también trabajan en la creación de antídotos contra las bioarmas enemigas (así como contra las propias). Por ello, dichos edificios se consideran esenciales para la defensa de una ciudad. A pesar de eso y, aunque dichos laboratorios biobélicos estén equipados con sofisticadas capas protectoras contra filtraciones, los vecinos no acostumbran a recibir bien a estas instalaciones.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Centers for Disease Control (or "CDC") are a group of linked government-supported facilities located in Atlanta, Georgia. The CDC is mandated to coordinate national anti-disease efforts, to develop and apply disease prevention techniques, to increase national awareness of disease, as well as to fund external research on disease prevention and control. [PARAGRAPH:1]Born in 1946, for most of its early history the CDC worked exclusively on naturally-created diseases such as typhus, malaria, influenza and the plague. However, as the twenty-first century has advanced, an ever-greater portion of its funding is being spent on countering man-made diseases. As population densities increase, citizens are at higher risk from so-called "designer plagues" deployed by terrorists or enemy missiles. A rapid response to such an attack may be all that saves a city from total annihilation.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les Centres de Contrôle et de Prévention des Maladies (ou CCPM) sont un ensemble d'installations financées par l'Etat et situées à Atlanta, en Géorgie. Les CCPM sont chargés de coordonner la recherche médicale au niveau national, de développer de nouvelles techniques de prévention, d'informer le grand public et de financer certains projets de recherche externes. [PARAGRAPH:1]Depuis leur fondation en 1946, les CCPM se sont surtout intéressés aux maladies naturelles telles que le typhus, la malaria, la grippe ou la peste. Mais depuis le vingt-deuxième siècle, une partie plus importante des recherches est consacrée aux maladies crées par l'homme. A mesure que la densité de population croît dans les grandes villes, les citoyens deviennent des cibles idéales pour les "pestes artificielles" déployées par les organisations terroristes ou les missiles ennemis. En cas d'attaque, seule l'existence d'antidotes pourrait sauver une ville entière de la destruction.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Centers for Disease Control (kurz "CDC") sind eine mit dem Bundesgesundheitsamt vergleichbare staatliche Behörde der Vereinigten Staaten mit Sitz in Atlanta, Georgia. Zu den Hauptaufgaben der CDC gehören die Koordination des nationalen Seuchenschutzes, die Entwicklung und Umsetzung von Methoden zur Seuchenprävention, medizinische Aufklärungsarbeit sowie die Finanzierung externer Forschungsprojekte für Krankheitsprävention und -bekämpfung. [PARAGRAPH:1]Im Jahr 1946 gegründet, konzentrierten sich die CDC zu Beginn ausschließlich auf die Bekämpfung von Krankheiten mit natürlichen Ursachen, wie Typhus, Malaria, Influenza und die Pest. Seit dem 21. Jahrhundert richtete sich ihr Augenmerk dann zunehmend auch auf die Bekämpfung von Krankheiten, die von Menschenhand verursacht wurden. Wegen steigender Bevölkerungsdichten sind die Bürger mittlerweile einem erhöhten Risiko ausgesetzt, einer so genannten "Designerkrankheit" zum Opfer zu fallen, die von Terroristen oder feindlichen Raketen ausgeht. Eine schnelle Reaktion auf einen solchen Angriff könnte ausschlaggebend dafür sein, dass eine Stadt vor der vollständigen Eliminierung bewahrt wird.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il Centro Controllo Malattie (Centers for Disease Control o CDC) è un gruppo di impianti che si trova ad Atlanta, Georgia, ed è stato realizzato col supporto del governo. Il compito del CDC è quello di coordinare i programmi nazionali anti malattia, di sviluppare e applicare tecniche di prevenzione delle malattie, di aumentare la consapevolezza nazionale sulle malattie e di finanziare ricerche esterne sulla prevenzione e sul controllo delle malattie. [PARAGRAPH:1]Sorto nel 1946, per la maggior parte della sua storia iniziale il CDC ha lavorato esclusivamente su malattie naturali come tifo, malaria, influenza e la peste. Con l'avanzare del ventunesimo secolo, però, una parte sempre più grande dei finanziamenti viene spesa per contrastare malattie create dall'uomo. Con l'incremento della densità degli abitanti, i cittadini sono più a rischio di contrarre "malattie progettate", diffuse da terroristi o da missili nemici. Una rapida reazione a questo tipo di attacco può essere l'unica speranza di salvare una città dallo stermini
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El Centro de Control de Enfermedades (o "CCE") es un grupo de instalaciones intercomunicadas y financiadas por el gobierno que se encuentran en Atlanta, Georgia. El CCE tiene la orden de coordinar los esfuerzos contra enfermedades a escala nacional, de desarrollar técnicas preventivas, de incrementar la concienciación nacional sobre las enfermedades, así como de financiar la investigación externa sobre la prevención y el control de las mismas. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nacido en 1946, en sus orígenes el CCE trabajaba exclusivamente en enfermedades de origen natural, como el tifus, la malaria, la gripe o la peste. Sin embargo, a medida que ha avanzado el s. XXI, una porción cada vez mayor de sus fondos se está destinando a hacer frente a enfermedades creadas por el ser humano. A medida que crece la densidad de población, los ciudadanos están cada vez más expuestos a las llamadas "enfermedades de diseño", propagadas por los terroristas o misiles enemigos. Una respuesta rápida a un ataque de esta naturaleza puede salvar a una ciudad del exterminio tota

TEXT.English: [TAB]Although fairly immune from the assaults of weather and other natural hazards, arcologies remain at high risk from human assault. To better protect themselves, the giant cities can add mechanical and electromagnetic shielding to their domes. While these are not totally effective against a determined assault, they do provide some measure of security to the civilian population.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Bien que potentiellement capables de résister aux variations climatiques et autres facteurs naturels, les arcologies restent extrêmement vulnérables aux attaques. Afin de se protéger, les villes géantes peuvent ajouter des boucliers mécaniques et électromagnétiques à leur dôme. Si ces dispositifs ne sont pas d'une efficacité totale en cas d'attaque, ils présentent l'avantage d'offrir une certaine protection aux populations civiles.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Obwohl sie relativ immun gegen extreme Witterungsbedingungen und andere Naturkatastrophen sind, besteht auch für Arkologien ein hohes Risiko, durch menschliche Angriffe beeinträchtigt zu werden. Um sich besser zu schützen, können die gigantischen Städte ihre Kuppeln daher mit einem mechanischen und elektromagnetischen Schild versehen. Diese können gezielte Angriffe zwar ebenfalls nicht zu einhundert Prozent abwehren, sie bieten der Zivilbevölkerung aber dennoch ein gewisses Maß an Sicherheit.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Anche se sono abbastanza immuni dagli attacchi del tempo e di altri pericoli naturali, le arcologie sono ad alto rischio di attacchi umani. Per proteggersi meglio, queste grandi città possono aggiungere scudi meccanici ed elettromagnetici alle loro cupole. Anche se non sono totalmente efficaci contro un attacco deciso, forniscono un certo grado di protezione alla popolazione civile.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]A pesar de ser bastante inmunes a las inclemencias climáticas y otras catástrofes naturales, las arcologías siguen sufriendo un gran riesgo de ser atacadas por los humanos. Para protegerse mejor, estas ciudades gigantes pueden añadir escudos mecánicos y electromagnéticos a sus cúpulas. Aunque no son completamente eficaces ante determinados ataques, ofrecen ciertas medidas de seguridad a la población civil.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A cloning factory is a massive building containing hundreds (and sometimes thousands) of vats of murky and disgusting liquid, in which float human clones in varying stages of development. Humans and computers monitor each vat closely, ensuring that the clone within is getting the proper amount of nutrients, heat, light and oxygen necessary for successful maturation. [PARAGRAPH:1]In earlier experiments scientists were unable to grow clones any faster than humans themselves grow, but as technology has increased, so has the speed with which clones mature. At present, a clone's body will reach full maturity in just over six years, while a human requires eighteen to twenty years to achieve the same development. [PARAGRAPH:1]While a clone's mental capacity is negligible, their organs and other parts are identical to human and can be transplanted into a human body with ease. Further, advances in technology have allowed computers to interface with clones' underdeveloped brains, creating zombie-like creatures capable of rudimentary physical labor.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une usine de clonage est un grand bâtiment qui peut contenir des centaines (voire des milliers) de cuves remplies d'un liquide visqueux, dans lequel des corps de clones humains poursuivent leur croissance. Des ingénieurs et des ordinateurs contrôlent chaque cuve pour s'assurer que le clone reçoit les doses de nutriments, de chaleur, de lumière et d'oxygène nécessaires à sa maturation. [PARAGRAPH:1]Au début du clonage, les scientifiques ne savaient pas développer un clone plus rapidement que le rythme de croissance humain normal. Mais les progrès de la technologie ont révolutionné cette pratique. Aujourd'hui, le corps d'un clone atteint en à peine six ans le niveau de développement d'un humain de vingt ans. [PARAGRAPH:1]Si les capacités mentales d'un clone sont insignifiantes, ses organes sont en tous points identiques à ceux de son modèle et peuvent facilement lui être transplantés. En outre, de nouveaux progrès technologiques ont permis d'implanter des programmes informatiques dans le cerveau des clones, qui peuvent ainsi être transformés en ouvriers capables de travaux rudimentaires.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Klonfabrik ist ein gewaltiges Gebäude, in dem hunderte (manchmal sogar tausende) mit trüber, recht ekliger Flüssigkeit gefüllte Behälter aufbewahrt werden, in denen menschliche Klone in unterschiedlichen Entwicklungsstadien ihr Dasein fristen. Menschen und Computer überwachen jeden dieser Behälter sorgsam, um sicherzustellen, dass der darin eingeschlossene Klon mit der richtigen Menge an Nährstoffen, Wärme, Licht und Sauerstoff versorgt wird, die für eine erfolgreiche Reifung nötig ist. [PARAGRAPH:1]In früheren Experimenten hatten es die Wissenschaftler nicht geschafft, Klone schneller reifen zu lassen, als in der Zeit, die auch der Mensch zum Heranwachsen braucht. Nach weiteren technologischen Fortschritten konnte die Klonreifung jedoch beschleunigt werden und so erreicht ein Klonkörper gegenwärtig in knapp über sechs Jahren seine volle Reife, während ein Mensch etwa 18 bis 20 Jahre für eine vergleichbare Entwicklung benötigt. [PARAGRAPH:1]Wenn man die mentale Kapazität eines Klons einmal außer Acht lässt, sind seine Organe und andere Körperteile mit denen des Menschen identisch und können daher problemlos in einen menschlichen Körper transplantiert werden. Außerdem ist es neuerdings dank moderner Technologie auch möglich, per Computerschnittstelle auf das unterentwickelte Gehirn eines Klons zuzugreifen, um ihn in ein Golem-artiges Wesen zu verwandeln, das auch rudimentäre körperliche Arbeiten verrichten kann.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Una fabbrica di cloni è un enorme edificio contenente centinaia (e talvolta migliaia) di vasche di liquido opaco e disgustoso, in cui galleggiano cloni umani in diversi stadi di sviluppo. Umani e computer controllano attentamente ogni vasca, assicurandosi che il clone all'interno riceva la giusta quantità di nutrienti, calore, luce e ossigeno necessaria per la maturazione. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nei primi esperimenti, gli scienziati erano incapaci di far crescere i cloni più rapidamente degli stessi umani, ma con l'incremento della tecnologia c'è stato un aumento della velocità di maturazione dei cloni. Al momento, il corpo di un clone raggiunge la piena maturità in poco più di sei anni, mentre un umano ci mette da diciotto a vent'anni per raggiungere lo stesso sviluppo. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mentre la capacità mentale di un clone è irrisoria, gli organi e le altre parti sono identiche a quelle umane e possono essere facilmente trapiantati in un corpo umano. Inoltre gli sviluppi tecnologici hanno permesso di interfacciare i computer con i cervelli sottosviluppati dei cloni, creando creature tipo zombi in grado di svolgere rudimentali lavori di fatica.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Una planta de clonación es un enorme edificio que cuenta con centenares (y a veces miles) de contenedores de líquido turbio y repugnante en el que flotan clones humanos en diversas fases de desarrollo. Cada recipiente es controlado atentamente por humanos y ordenadores para asegurarse de que el clon que contiene cuente con la cantidad apropiada de nutrientes, calor, luz y oxígeno necesarios para madurar con éxito. [PARAGRAPH:1]Durante los primeros experimentos, los científicos fueron incapaces de hacer crecer clones a más velocidad que la del crecimiento humano, pero, a medida que la tecnología avanzaba, también lo hacía la velocidad a la que maduraban los clones. Actualmente, el cuerpo de un clon alcanza la madurez total en solo seis años, mientras que un humano precisa entre dieciocho y veinte años para alcanzar el mismo nivel. [PARAGRAPH:1]Aunque la capacidad mental de un clon es insignificantes, los órganos y otras partes del cuerpo son idénticas a los humanos y pueden transplantarse fácilmente. Además, los avances tecnológicos permiten conectar ordenadores a clones con cerebros atrofiados, creando así criaturas similares a zombis que son capaces de hacer trabajos físicos rudimentarios.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Civil scientists and engineers are ever on the lookout for ways to improve a city's defense against enemy attack. Today's advanced shielding is a combination of several different successful lines of research. Advanced shields are made of far tougher semi-organic material designed to "scab over" and repair breaches in its surface. The electromagnetic shielding has been improved as well, increasing the overall strength of the shielding. While even the advanced shielding is less than perfect and can be overcome by determined attack, cities employing these defenses are far less vulnerable than unprotected cities.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les scientifiques et les ingénieurs civils ont toujours cherché des moyens d'améliorer les défenses d'une ville contre les attaques ennemies. Les boucliers de pointe que nous connaissons aujourd'hui sont la combinaison de plusieurs découvertes technologiques. Ils sont en effet fabriqués dans un matériau semi-organique très résistant et conçu pour "cicatriser" si une brèche s'ouvrait. Les boucliers électromagnétiques ont également été modernisés, ce qui accroît encore l'efficacité du dispositif. Le niveau de défense atteint par les boucliers de pointe n'est pas encore parfait, mais les villes qui les utilisent restent beaucoup moins vulnérables que les autres.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Zivile Wissenschaftler und Ingenieure sind stets auf der Suche nach Möglichkeiten, die Verteidigungsfähigkeit einer Stadt gegen feindliche Angriffe zu verbessern. Die heute verfügbare fortgeschrittene Schildtechnologie ist das Resultat einer Reihe verschiedener Forschungsprojekte. Fortgeschrittene Schilde sind aus sehr widerstandsfähigem semi-organischen Material gefertigt, das es ermöglicht, Risse an der Oberfläche abzuschirmen und instand zu setzen. Und auch die elektromagnetische Schildgeneration wurde verbessert, so dass die Schilde nun eine erhöhte Gesamtstärke aufweisen. Die fortgeschrittenen Schilde sind zwar nach wie vor nicht perfekt, sondern können durch gezielte Angriffe überwunden werden, dennoch bieten sie Städten, in denen sie eingesetzt werden, deutlich mehr Sicherheit als dies in ungeschützten Städten der Fall ist.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Scienziati e ingegneri civili sono sempre alla ricerca per trovare il modo di migliorare le difese cittadine contro gli attacchi nemici. Gli scudi avanzati attuali sono una combinazione di diverse linee di ricerca di successo. Gli scudi avanzati sono realizzati con un materiale semi-organico estremamente resistente e progettato per autoriparare le falle nella superficie. Anche la protezione elettromagnetica è migliorata, aumentando la forza totale degli scudi. Lo scudo avanzato non è certo perfetto e può essere distrutto da un attacco deciso, ma le città che utilizzano queste difese sono molto meno vulnerabili di quelle non protett
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los ingenieros y científicos civiles siempre están buscando nuevas maneras de mejorar la defensa de una ciudad contra los ataques. Los escudos de hoy en día son una combinación de varias líneas de investigación logradas. Están fabricados de material semiorgánico mucho más duro, diseñado para "costrificarse" y reparar las brechas que aparezcan en su superficie. La protección electromagnética también ha mejorado, aumentando así la fuerza total de los escudos. Aunque los escudos avanzados distan de ser perfectos y pueden ser derribados por un ataque decidido, las ciudades que emplean estas defensas son mucho menos vulnerables que las que están desprotegida

TEXT.English: [TAB]As populations continue to grow, pushing human stress and unhappiness to unacceptably high levels, some cities are turning to mind-control centers to help alleviate the problem. Popularly known as "fun zones," these buildings broadcast a constant stream of soothing and enjoyable light entertainment which can be experienced by any human in the city equipped with a neural receiver (colloquially known as a "brain-jack"). [PARAGRAPH:1]While a "jacked-in" subject's productivity, creativity and intellect are somewhat impaired. However, the person is virtually incapable of being unhappy, no matter what the circumstances - so long as the constant barrage of meaningless entertainment is poured into their otherwise vacant brains. [PARAGRAPH:1]Despite its benefits, constructing a mind control center is not to be undertaken lightly: the broadcasts have been found to be nearly 100% addictive, and cutting an addict off from them may cause massive mental trauma ranging from catatonia to deep depression to homicidal rage. In other words, once a city's population is jacked in, there's no turning back - and a city had better have plenty of backups in case of broadcast equipment failure.
TEXT.French: [TAB]A mesure que les populations continuent de croître, augmentant le stress et le mécontentement dans les villes, le recours aux centres de contrôle mental tend à se généraliser. Mieux connus sous le nom de "zones d'amusement", ces bâtiments diffusent en permanence un flux d'images joyeuses accessibles à tous les individus équipés d'un récepteur neural (aussi appelé "implant cérébral"). [PARAGRAPH:1]Si les personnes dotées d'implants cérébraux voient généralement leur productivité, leur créativité et leur intellect se détériorer, elles ne ressentent plus aucun mécontentement, quelles que soient les circonstances - à condition que des signaux continuent à accaparer l'attention de leurs cerveaux. [PARAGRAPH:1]Malgré tous les avantages qu'il présente, construire un centre de contrôle mental n'est pas une décision à prendre à la légère. Le taux de dépendance des individus équipés d'un implant est de 100% et en cas de manque, le traumatisme mental peut aller de la catatonie à la folie meurtrière. Autrement dit, une fois qu'une ville a adopté ce système, elle ne peut plus faire machine arrière. Il est en outre impératif de prévoir des solutions de secours en cas de panne.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Mit ständig wachsenden Bevölkerungszahlen stiegen auch Stress und Unzufriedenheit in den Städten auf ein unerträglich hohes Niveau, so dass manche dazu übergingen, diesem Problem durch Bewusstseinskontrollzentren zu begegnen. Diese allgemein als "Spaßzonen" bekannten Gebäude senden einen dauerhaften Strom beruhigender und amüsanter Unterhaltungsdaten aus, die von jedem Menschen in der Stadt empfangen werden können, der mit einem Neuralempfänger ausgestattet ist (umgangssprachlich auch "Hirnstecker" genannt). [PARAGRAPH:1]Während der "Einsteckphase" sind Produktivität, Kreativität und Intellektualität der Betreffenden etwas beeinträchtigt, andererseits sind sie in diesem Zustand unabhängig von den aktuellen Umständen praktisch unfähig, Unzufriedenheit zu entwickeln - solange die harmlose Unterhaltungsberieselung auf ihre ansonsten leer gefegten Gehirne anhält. [PARAGRAPH:1]Trotz der Vorzüge sollte die Errichtung eines Bewusstseinskontrollzentrums jedoch nicht leichtfertig erfolgen: Es gilt als erwiesen, dass die ausgestrahlten Datenströme zu nahezu 100%% süchtig machen und einen Süchtigen abzukoppeln, kann ein massives mentales Trauma nach sich ziehen, angefangen von einem katatonischen Zustand über tiefe Depressionen bis hin zu mörderischer Rage. Mit anderen Worten: Sobald die Bürger einmal eingesteckt waren, gibt es kein Zurück mehr - und die Stadt sollte für den Fall, dass die Sendeanlagen einmal ausfallen, besser über ausreichende Sicherungssysteme verfügen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Con il continuo aumento della popolazione, che porta stress e infelicità a livelli inaccettabilmente alti, alcune città si stanno rivolgendo a centri di controllo mentale per aiutare ad alleviare il problema. Conosciuti comunemente come "posti divertenti", questi edifici trasmettono un flusso costante di intrattenimento leggero, calmante e divertente di cui può usufruire qualsiasi cittadino equipaggiato con un ricevitore neurale (colloquialmente definito "presa del cervello"). [PARAGRAPH:1]Quando un soggetto è "attaccato alla presa" la sua produttività, la sua creatività e il suo intelletto sono in qualche modo ridotti. Però la persona è virtualmente incapace di essere infelice, a prescindere dalle circostanze, fino a quando l'assedio di insensato intrattenimento continua a essere trasmesso al suo cervello. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nonostante i benefici, la costruzione di un centro di controllo mentale non deve essere intrapresa alla leggera: si è scoperto che le trasmissioni causano dipendenza al 100% e scollegare una persona assuefatta può portare a enormi traumi mentali che vanno dalla catatonia alla depressione alla rabbia omicida. In altre parole, una volta che la popolazione di una città è "collegata alla presa" non si torna indietro. E sarà meglio per la città avere molte scorte, in caso di guasto ai sistemi di trasmission
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]A medida que la población crece y el estrés y la infelicidad llegan a unas cotas inaceptables, algunas ciudades se vuelcan en los centros de control mental para mitigar el problema. Llamados popularmente "zonas de recreo", estos edificios emiten un flujo constante de diversión balsámica que puede sentir cualquier individuo de la ciudad equipado con un receptor neuronal (conocido coloquialmente como "enchufe cerebral"). [PARAGRAPH:1]No obstante, la productividad, la creatividad y la razón de los "enchufados" se ven algo limitadas. Pese a ello, la persona es prácticamente incapaz de sentirse infeliz, por adversas que sean sus circunstancias, siempre y cuando el barrido constante de diversión sinsentido se vuelque en su cerebro, que, de lo contrario, seguiría vacío. [PARAGRAPH:1]Pese a estos beneficios, construir un centro de control mental no es algo que deba tomarse a la ligera: se ha descubierto que las emisiones son completamente adictivas y privar de ellas a un adicto podría causarle traumas mentales generalizados que van desde la catatonia hasta la depresión profunda pasando por los impulsos homicidas. En otras palabras: una vez se "enchufe" la población de una ciudad, no hay vuelta atrás. Y mejor que el consistorio tenga una buena provisión de copias de seguridad por si el equipo llegara a fallar.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The original League of Nations was created after World War I in an effort to ensure that such a calamitous event could never recur. Although the League was largely a brainchild of US president Woodrow Wilson, the United States Congress wanted nothing to do with the new organization, and, lacking any military force or financial support from the Great Powers, the League was unable to stop the world from the horrible chaos of the Second World War, and so the organization died. [PARAGRAPH:1]After that war, the concept of the League of Nations was revived in the United Nations, an organization backed - at least at first - by the full support of the United States. And while the UN was notably inefficient and (some said) corrupt, and though it had no military force of its own, it survived for many years, during which time the world did not fall prey to yet another world war. With the rise of the One World Government, the UN lost the reason for its existence, and it too was relegated to the "dustbin of history." [PARAGRAPH:1]As the One World Government has collapsed and humanity seems to be moving inexorably towards another worldwide conflict, there have been recent efforts to create a "New League of Nations" based in large upon the at least semi-successful UN model. It is yet unsure whether this effort will succeed, and if it does, whether the New League of Nations will be able to deflect the planet from its march toward self-destruction.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La première Société des Nations fut fondée après la première guerre mondiale afin de s'assurer qu'un tel événement ne se reproduirait jamais. Cette Société devait en grande partie son existence au président des Etats-Unis, Woodrow Wilson, mais le Congrès américain refusa de collaborer avec elle. Dépourvue de toute force militaire et disposant de moyens financiers dérisoires, la Société des Nations ne fut pas en mesure de prévenir le terrible chaos de la deuxième guerre mondiale et fut dissoute. [PARAGRAPH:1]Après la guerre, le concept de Société des Nations se trouva à nouveau exploité lors de la création de l'Organisation des Nations Unies, qui obtint dans un premier temps l'assentiment total des Etats-Unis. L'ONU, disposant de sa propre armée, resta en place pendant de nombreuses années, malgré une réputation entachée d'accusations d'inefficacité et de corruption. Avec la création du Gouvernement Mondial, l'ONU cessa d'exister. [PARAGRAPH:1]Depuis la chute du Gouvernement Mondial, la crainte de voir l'humanité à nouveau sur la voie d'un conflit mondial mena à la création d'une Nouvelle Société des Nations, sur le modèle de ce qu'avait été l'ONU. Toutefois, nul ne peut affirmer que cela suffira à apaiser les tensions, ni si la Nouvelle Société des Nations sera en mesure d'empêcher la planète de courir à l'autodestruction.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der ursprüngliche Völkerbund wurde nach dem Ersten Weltkrieg in dem Bestreben gegründet, sicherzustellen, dass ein derartig verhängnisvolles Ereignis nie wieder stattfinden würde. Obwohl diese neue Organisation größtenteils auf eine Idee des U.S.-amerikanischen Präsidenten Woodrow Wilson zurückzuführen war, wollte der amerikanische Kongress jedoch nichts damit zu schaffen haben. Und weil es auch an militärischer und finanzieller Unterstützung seitens der Großmächte mangelte, war der Völkerbund am Ende nicht in der Lage, die Welt vor der verheerenden Katastrophe des Zweiten Weltkrieges zu bewahren und wurde aufgelöst. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nach dem Krieg wurde das Konzept des Völkerbundes dann in Form der Vereinten Nationen wiederbelebt, einer Organisation, die dieses Mal - endlich und erstmals - auch die volle Unterstützung der Vereinigten Staaten von Amerika erhielt. Zwar herrschte in den Vereinten Nationen mitunter ein spürbares Maß an Ineffizienz und (wie manche behaupteten) Korruption vor und sie unterhielten auch keine eigenen Militärtruppen, dennoch blieben sie viele Jahre lang bestehen, in denen die Welt keinen weiteren Weltkrieg erdulden musste. Durch die Bildung der Weltregierung verloren die Vereinten Nationen allerdings ihre Daseinsberechtigung und wurden somit ebenfalls in den "Abfalleimer der Geschichte" befördert. [PARAGRAPH:1]Da die Menschheit seit dem Zerfall der Weltregierung mittlerweile wieder scheinbar unaufhaltsam auf einen neuen weltweiten militärischen Konflikt zusteuert, gab es in jüngster Vergangenheit Bemühungen, einen "Neuen Völkerbund" zu bilden, der vorwiegend auf dem zumindest halbwegs erfolgreichen Modell der Vereinten Nationen basieren soll. Noch steht allerdings nicht fest, ob diese Bemühungen von Erfolg gekrönt sein werden, und, wenn ja, ob der Neue Völkerbund wirklich in der Lage sein wird, den Planeten vor der Selbstzerstörung zu bewahren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La Società delle Nazioni originale venne creata dopo la Prima Guerra Mondiale nel tentativo di evitare che cose simili accadessero ancora. Anche se la Società era principalmente frutto dell'impegno del presidente USA Woodrow Wilson, il Congresso degli Stati Uniti non volle averci nulla a che fare e, mancando una qualsiasi forza militare o un supporto finanziario da parte delle Grandi Potenze, la Società non riuscì a impedire l'orribile caos della Seconda Guerra Mondiale e si sfaldò. [PARAGRAPH:1]Dopo quella guerra l'idea della Società delle Nazioni venne fatta rivivere nelle Nazioni Unite, un'organizzazione supportata, almeno inizialmente, appieno dagli Stati Uniti. E l'organizzazione, pur essendo poco efficiente e (alcuni dicono) corrotta, e non avendo un proprio esercito, sopravvisse per molti anni durante i quali il mondo non ricadde in un'altra guerra mondiale. Con la creazione di un governo mondiale, le nazioni Unite non ebbero più motivo di esistere e vennero relegate nel "cestino della storia." [PARAGRAPH:1]Col crollo del governo mondiale, l'umanità sembra muoversi inesorabilmente verso un altro conflitto globale, ma ci sono stati dei tentativi di creare una "Nuova Società delle Nazioni" basata in gran parte sul modello semi-riuscito delle Nazioni Unite. Non si sa ancora se questo tentativo andrà a buon fine e, se ce la fa, se la Nuova Società delle Nazioni sarà in grado di distogliere il pianeta dalla marcia verso l'autodistruzion
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La Sociedad de Naciones original se creó tras la Primera Guerra Mundial en un esfuerzo por que esa calamidad nunca volviera a ocurrir. Aunque la Sociedad era en gran parte hija del presidente norteamericano Woodrow Wilson, el congreso de los Estados Unidos no quiso saber nada de esa organización y, a falta de la fuerza militar o el apoyo económico de las grandes potencias, la Sociedad fue incapaz de impedir que el mundo cayera en el horrible caos de la Segunda Guerra Mundial, por lo que se disolvió. [PARAGRAPH:1]Tras la guerra, la idea de las Sociedad se reencarnó en las Naciones Unidas, una organización respaldada, al menos al principio, incondicionalmente por los Estados Unidos. Y, pese a que la ONU fue notablemente ineficaz y (a decir de algunos) corrupta, y a que carecía de fuerzas militares propias, sobrevivió durante muchos años, tiempo durante el cual la Tierra no cayó presa de otra guerra mundial. Con el auge del Gobierno Único Mundial, la ONU perdió la razón de su existencia y quedó relegada a la "papelera de la historia". [PARAGRAPH:1]Como el Gobierno Único Mundial ha caído y la humanidad parece avanzar inexorablemente hacia otro conflicto global, ha habido esfuerzos recientes para crear una "Nueva Sociedad de Naciones" basada a grandes rasgos en el modelo semiexitoso de la ONU. Se desconoce aún si estos esfuerzos se materializarán y, si de hacerlo, la Nueva Sociedad de Naciones conseguirá apartar al planeta de su marcha hacia la autodestrucció

TEXT.English: [TAB]Petra is an archaeological site in southwestern Jordan, lying on the slope of Mount Hor in a basin among the mountains which form the eastern flank of Arabah (Wadi Araba), the large valley running from the Dead Sea to the Gulf of Aqaba. It is renowned for its rock-cut architecture. [PARAGRAPH:1]The site remained unknown to the Western world until 1812, when it was discovered by Swiss explorer Johann Ludwig Burckhardt. It was famously described as "a rose-red city half as old as time" in a Newdigate prize-winning sonnet by John William Burgon. UNESCO has described it as "one of the most precious cultural properties of man's cultural heritage." In 1985, Petra was designated a World Heritage Site. It is one of the "New Seven Wonders of the World" as determined by the New Open World Corporation (not affiliated with UNESCO).

TEXT.English: [TAB]A convention center, in American English, is an exhibition hall, or conference center, that is designed to hold a convention. In British English very large venues suitable for major trade shows are known as exhibition centers while the term "convention centre" is sometimes used for intermediate venues between exhibitions centers and "conference centers", which are much smaller and contain lecture halls and meeting rooms. Convention centers are typically large, cavernous public buildings with enough open space to host public and private business and social events for their surrounding municipal and metropolitan areas. Convention centers typically offer enough floor area to accommodate several thousand attendees. Convention centers rent space for meetings such as: corporate conferences, industry trade shows, formal dances entertainment spectacles and concerts. The largest in the United States is McCormick Place in Chicago. Large convention centers located in resort areas also host conventions that attract additional visitors to the municipality. It is not uncommon for large resort area hotels to include a convention center.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Quality control and quality engineering are used in developing systems to ensure products or services are designed and produced to meet or exceed customer requirements.[PARAGRAPH:2]Quality control is the branch of engineering and manufacturing which deals with assurance and failure testing in design and production of products or services, to meet or exceed customer requirements.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The theory of everything (TOE) is a putative theory of theoretical physics that fully explains and links together all known physical phenomena. Initially, the term was used with an ironic connotation to refer to various overgeneralized theories. For example, a great-grandfather of Ijon Tichy - a character from a cycle of Stanislaw Lem's science fiction stories of 1960s — was known to work on the "General Theory of Everything". Physicist John Ellis claims to have introduced the term into the technical literature in an article in Nature in 1986. Over time, the term stuck in popularizations of quantum physics to describe a theory that would unify or explain through a single model the theories of all fundamental interactions of nature.[PARAGRAPH:2]There have been many theories of everything proposed by theoretical physicists over the last century, but none has been confirmed experimentally. The primary problem in producing a TOE is that the accepted theories of quantum mechanics and general relativity are hard to combine.[PARAGRAPH:2]Based on theoretical holographic principle arguments from the 1990s, many physicists believe that 11-dimensional M-theory, which is described in many sectors by matrix string theory, in many other sectors by perturbative string theory is the complete theory of everything, although there is no widespread consensus and M-theory is not a completed theory but rather an approach for producing one.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the late 1990s, it was noted that one problem with several of the candidates for theories of everything (but particularly string theory) was that they did not constrain the characteristics of the predicted universe. For example, many theories of quantum gravity can create universes with arbitrary numbers of dimensions or with arbitrary cosmological constants. Even the "standard" ten-dimensional string theory allows the "curled up" dimensions to be compactified in an enormous number of different ways each of which corresponds to a different collection of fundamental particles and low-energy forces. This array of theories is known as the string theory landscape.[PARAGRAPH:2]A speculative solution is that many or all of these possibilities are realised in one or another of a huge number of universes, but that only a small number of them are habitable, and hence the fundamental constants of the universe are ultimately the result of the anthropic principle rather than a consequence of the theory of everything. This anthropic approach is often criticised in that, because the theory is flexible enough to encompass almost any observation, it cannot make useful (as in original, falsifiable, and verifiable) predictions. In this view, string theory would be considered a pseudoscience, where an unfalsifiable theory is constantly adapted to fit the experimental results.

TEXT.English: An artesian aquifer is a confined aquifer containing groundwater that will flow upwards out of a well without the need for pumping. An aquifer provides the water for an artesian well. An aquifer is a layer of soft rock, like limestone or sandstone, that absorbs water from an inlet path. Porous stone is crushed between impermeable rocks or clay. This keeps the pressure high, so when the water finds a hole, it overcomes gravity and goes up instead of down.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Radar is an object detection system that uses electromagnetic waves to identify the range, altitude, direction, or speed of both moving and fixed objects such as aircraft, ships, motor vehicles, weather formations, and terrain. The term RADAR was coined in 1941 as an acronym for RAdio Detection And Ranging.[PARAGRAPH:2]A radar system has a transmitter that emits microwaves or radio waves. These waves are in phase when emitted, and when they come into contact with an object are scattered in all directions. The signal is thus partly reflected back and it has a slight change of wavelength (and thus frequency) if the target is moving. The receiver is usually, but not always, in the same location as the transmitter. Although the signal returned is usually very weak, the signal can be amplified through use of electronic techniques in the receiver and in the antenna configuration. This enables radar to detect objects at ranges where other emissions, such as sound or visible light, would be too weak to detect. Radar uses include meteorological detection of precipitation, measuring ocean surface waves, air traffic control, police detection of speeding traffic, determining the speed of baseballs and by the military.

The term RADAR was coined in 1941 as an acronym for RAdio Detection And Ranging.[PARAGRAPH:2]A radar system has a transmitter that emits microwaves or radio waves. These waves are in phase when emitted, and when they come into contact with an object are scattered in all directions. The signal is thus partly reflected back and it has a slight change of wavelength (and thus frequency) if the target is moving. The receiver is usually, but not always, in the same location as the transmitter. Although the signal returned is usually very weak, the signal can be amplified through use of electronic techniques in the receiver and in the antenna configuration. This enables radar to detect objects at ranges where other emissions, such as sound or visible light, would be too weak to detect. Radar uses include meteorological detection of precipitation, measuring ocean surface waves, air traffic control, police detection of speeding traffic, determining the speed of baseballs and by the military.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Radar is an object detection system that uses electromagnetic waves to identify the range, altitude, direction, or speed of both moving and fixed objects such as aircraft, ships, motor vehicles, weather formations, and terrain. The term RADAR was coined in 1941 as an acronym for RAdio Detection And Ranging.[PARAGRAPH:2]A radar system has a transmitter that emits microwaves or radio waves. This enables radar to detect objects at ranges where other emissions, such as sound or visible light, would be too weak to detect. Radar uses include meteorological detection of precipitation, measuring ocean surface waves, air traffic control, police detection of speeding traffic, determining the speed of baseballs and by the military.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A chemical plant is an industrial process plant that manufactures (or otherwise processes) chemicals, usually on a large scale. The general objective of a chemical plant is to create new material wealth via the chemical or biological transformation and or separation of materials. Chemical plants use special equipment, units, and technology in the processes. Other kinds of plants, such as polymer, pharmaceutical, food, and some beverage production facilities, power plants, oil refineries or other refineries, natural gas processing and biochemical plants, water and wastewater treatment, and pollution control equipment use many technologies which have similarities to chemical plant technology such as fluid systems. Some would consider an oil refinery or a pharmaceutical or polymer manufacturer to be effectively a chemical plant. Petrochemical plants (plants using petroleum as a raw material) are usually located adjacent to an oil refinery to minimize transportation costs for the feedstocks produced by the refinery.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A manor house or fortified manor-house is a country house, which has historically formed the administrative centre of a manor, the lowest unit of territorial organisation in the feudal system. The term is sometimes applied to relatively small country houses which belonged to gentry families, as well as to grand stately homes, particularly as a technical term for minor late medieval fortified country houses intended more for show than for defence. [PARAGRAPH:2]In general terms, the manor house was the dwelling house, or "capital messuage", of a feudal lord of a manor, which he occupied only on occasional visits if he held many manors. As such it was the place in which sessions of his "court baron", or manor court, were held. Sometimes a steward or seneschal was appointed by the seigniorial lord to oversee and manage his different manorial properties. The day-to-day administration was delegated to a bailiff, or reeve. [PARAGRAPH:2]Although not typically built with strong fortifications as castles were, many manor houses were partly fortified: they were enclosed within walls or ditches that often included the farm buildings as well. Many of them were equipped with small gatehouses and watchtowers. The primary feature of the manor house was its Great Hall, to which subsidiary apartments were added as the lessening of feudal warfare permitted more peaceful domestic life. [PARAGRAPH:2]By the beginning of the 16th century, manor houses as well as small castles began to acquire the character and amenities of the residences of country gentlemen. This late 16th century transformation produced many of the smaller Renaissance châteaux of France and the numerous country mansions of the Elizabethan and Jacobean styles in England.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Agora was an open "place of assembly" in ancient Greek city-states. Early in Greek history (900s - 700s BCE), free-born male land-owners who were citizens would gather in the agora for military duty or to hear statements of the ruling king or council. Later in Greek history, the agora served as a marketplace where merchants kept stalls or shops to sell their goods under colonnades.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Irrigation canals are artificial channels for water. The oldest known irrigation canals were built in Mesopotamia circa 4000 BC, in what is now modern day Iraq and Syria. The Indus Valley Civilization in Pakistan and North India (circa 2600 BC) had sophisticated irrigation and storage systems developed, including the reservoirs built at Girnar in 3000 BC. In Egypt, canals date back at least to the time of Pepi I Meryre (reigned 2332–2283 BC), who ordered a canal built to bypass the cataract on the Nile near Aswan.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Tanning is the process of converting putrescible skin into non-putrescible leather, usually with tannin, an acidic chemical compound that prevents decomposition and often imparts color. Tanning leather involves a process which permanently alters the protein structure of skin so that it can not ever return to rawhide. [PARAGRAPH:2]In ancient history, tanning was considered a noxious or "odiferous trade" and relegated to the outskirts of town, amongst the poor. Indeed, tanning by ancient methods is so foul smelling that tanneries are still isolated from those towns today where the old methods are used. The ancients used leather for waterskins, bags, harnesses, boats, armor, quivers, scabbards, boots and sandals. Around 2500 BC, the Sumerians began using leather, affixed by copper studs, on chariot wheels. [PARAGRAPH:2]Skins typically arrived at the tannery dried stiff and dirty with soil and gore. First, the ancient tanners would soak the skins in water to clean and soften them. Then they would pound and scour the skin to remove any remaining flesh and fat. Next, the tanner needed to remove the hair fibers from the skin. This was done by either soaking the skin in urine, painting it with an alkaline lime mixture, or simply letting the skin putrefy for several months then dipping it in a salt solution. After the hair fibers were loosened, the tanners scraped them off with a knife. [PARAGRAPH:2]Once the hair was removed, the tanners would bate the material (see below) by pounding dung into the skin or soaking the skin in a solution of animal brains. Among the kinds of dung commonly used were that of dogs or pigeons. Sometimes the dung was mixed with water in a large vat, and the prepared skins were kneaded in the dung water until they became supple, but not too soft. The ancient tanner might use his bare feet to knead the skins in the dung water, and the kneading could last two or three hours. It was this combination of urine, animal feces and decaying flesh that made ancient tanneries so odiferous.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A baker is someone who primarily bakes and sells bread. Cakes and similar foods may also be produced, as the traditional boundaries between what is produced by a baker as opposed to a pastry chef have blurred in recent decades. The place where a baker works is called a bakehouse, bakeshop, or bakery. [PARAGRAPH:2]The first group of people to bake bread were ancient Egyptians, in 2600-2100 BC. It was believed that they learnt their skills from the Babylonians. In the royal bakery of Ramesses, bread and cakes were often made in shapes of animals and used for sacrifices. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Greek culture influenced the Romans a lot after the Egyptians. From there, Bakery was transformed and flourished. The Romans were lusty and festive, soon the art of Bakering were a highly respected profession during the fourth century (A.D). The "job" was so profitable that in the time of Christ there were about three hundred Bakers around Rome. [PARAGRAPH:2]From the Roman Empire, the art of Bakery spread throughout Europe and the rest of the world. During the Middle ages, it was common for each landlord to have a bakery, which was actually more of a public oven. Housewives would bring dough that they had prepared to the baker, who would use the oven to bake it into bread. As time went on, bakers began to bake their own goods, creating numerous tricks. For example, some bakers had trap doors that would allow a small boy to pinch off a bit of the dough to later sell off as his own. This practice eventually led in England to a regulation known as the Assize of Bread and Ale, which provided harsh punishments for bakers who were caught cheating. In response, bakers commonly threw in an extra loaf of bread; this tradition lives on in the modern "baker's dozen".

TEXT.German: [TAB]A baker is someone who primarily bakes and sells bread. Cakes and similar foods may also be produced, as the traditional boundaries between what is produced by a baker as opposed to a pastry chef have blurred in recent decades. The place where a baker works is called a bakehouse, bakeshop, or bakery. [PARAGRAPH:2]The first group of people to bake bread were ancient Egyptians, in 2600-2100 BC. It was believed that they learnt their skills from the Babylonians. In the royal bakery of Ramesses, bread and cakes were often made in shapes of animals and used for sacrifices. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Greek culture influenced the Romans a lot after the Egyptians. From there, Bakery was transformed and flourished. The Romans were lusty and festive, soon the art of Bakering were a highly respected profession during the fourth century (A.D). The "job" was so profitable that in the time of Christ there were about three hundred Bakers around Rome. [PARAGRAPH:2]From the Roman Empire, the art of Bakery spread throughout Europe and the rest of the world. During the Middle ages, it was common for each landlord to have a bakery, which was actually more of a public oven. Housewives would bring dough that they had prepared to the baker, who would use the oven to bake it into bread. As time went on, bakers began to bake their own goods, creating numerous tricks. For example, some bakers had trap doors that would allow a small boy to pinch off a bit of the dough to later sell off as his own. This practice eventually led in England to a regulation known as the Assize of Bread and Ale, which provided harsh punishments for bakers who were caught cheating. In response, bakers commonly threw in an extra loaf of bread; this tradition lives on in the modern "baker's dozen".

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Great Mosque of Djenné is the largest mud brick or adobe building in the world and is considered by many architects to be the greatest achievement of the Sudano-Sahelian architectural style, albeit with definite Islamic influences. The mosque is located in the city of Djenné, Mali on the flood plain of the Bani River. The first mosque on the site was built in the 13th century, but the current structure dates from 1907. As well as being the centre of the community of Djenné, it is one of the most famous landmarks in Africa. Along with the "Old Towns of Djenné" it was designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1988.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A foundry is a factory that produces metal castings from either ferrous or non-ferrous alloys. Metals are turned into parts by melting the metal into a liquid, pouring the metal in a mold, and then removing the mold material or casting. The most common metal alloys processed are aluminum and cast iron. However, other metals, such as steel, magnesium, copper, tin, and zinc, can be processed.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A pharmacy (commonly the chemist in Australia, New Zealand and the UK; or drugstore in North America; retail pharmacy in industry terminology; or Apothecary, historically) is the place where most pharmacists practice the profession of pharmacy. It is the community pharmacy where the dichotomy of the profession exists-health professionals who are also retailers. [PARAGRAPH:2]Community pharmacies usually consist of a retail storefront with a dispensary where medications are stored and dispensed. The dispensary is subject to pharmacy legislation; with requirements for storage conditions, compulsory texts, equipment, etc., specified in legislation. Where it was once the case that pharmacists stayed within the dispensary compounding/dispensing medications; there has been an increasing trend towards the use of trained pharmacy technicians while the pharmacist spends more time communicating with patients.[PARAGRAPH:2]All pharmacies are required to have a pharmacist on-duty at all times when open. In many jurisdictions, it is also a requirement that the owner of a pharmacy must be a registered pharmacist (R.Ph.). This latter requirement has been revoked in many jurisdictions, such that many retailers (including supermarkets and mass merchandisers) now include a pharmacy as a department of their store.[PARAGRAPH:2]Likewise, many pharmacies are now rather grocery store-like in their design. In addition to medicines and prescriptions, many now sell a diverse arrangement of additional household items such as cosmetics, shampoo, office supplies, confectionary, and snack foods.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The first telephones had no network but were in private use, wired together in pairs. Users who wanted to talk to different people had as many telephones as necessary for the purpose. A user who wished to speak, whistled into the transmitter until the other party heard. Soon, however, a bell was added for signalling, and then a switchhook, and telephones took advantage of the exchange principle already employed in telegraph networks. Each telephone was wired to a local telephone exchange, and the exchanges were wired together with trunks. Networks were connected together in a hierarchical manner until they spanned cities, countries, continents and oceans. This was the beginning of the PSTN, though the term was unknown for many decades.[PARAGRAPH:2]Automation introduced pulse dialing between the phone and the exchange, and then among exchanges, followed by more sophisticated address signaling including multi-frequency, culminating in the SS7 network that connected most exchanges by the end of the 20th century.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Siege Weapon[COLOR_REVERT] is a device that is designed to break or circumvent city walls and other fortifications in siege warfare. [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Siege Weapons Workshops[COLOR_REVERT] are places where engineers developed Siege Weapons.
